byline.contributor: Mark Scott reported from London, and Aurelien Breeden from Paris.
byline.original: By MARK SCOTT and AURELIEN BREEDEN

abstract: French-Dutch digital security company Gemalto says it believes American and British intelligence services hacked into company's networks over period of two years, beginning in 2010, in order to collect mobile phone records; report is based on records obtained by former National Security Agency contractor Edward Snowden.
lead_paragraph: The digital security company said it believed attacks by the N.S.A. and its British counterpart occurred over two years, starting in 2010.

headline.main: U.S. and British Agencies May Have Tried to Get SIM Encryption Codes, Gemalto Says
headline.print_headline: Spy Agencies May Have Sought SIM Encryption Codes

snippet: The digital security company said it believed attacks by the N.S.A. and its British counterpart occurred over two years, starting in 2010.
